lines.text: Enter DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO and MOTH

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: Warble, child make passionate my sense of hearing.

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: Concolinel. DON
Singing

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: Sweet air! Go, tenderness of years take this key, give enlargement to the swain, bring him festinately hither: I must employ him in a letter to my love.

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: Master, will you win your love with a French brawl DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: How meanest thou brawling in French

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: No, my complete master: but to jig off a tune at the tongues end, canary to it with your feet, humour it with turning up your eyelids, sigh a note and sing a note, sometime through the throat, as if you swallowed love with singing love, sometime through the nose, as if you snuffed up love by smelling love with your hat penthouselike oer the shop of your eyes with your arms crossed on your thinbelly doublet like a rabbit on a spit or your hands in your pocket like a man after the old painting and keep not too long in one tune, but a snip and away. These are complements, these are humours these betray nice wenches, that would be betrayed without these and make them men of notedo you note methat most are affected to these. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: How hast thou purchased this experience

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: By my penny of observation. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: But O,but O,

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: The hobbyhorse is forgot. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: Callest thou my love hobbyhorse

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: No, master the hobbyhorse is but a colt, and your love perhaps a hackney. But have you forgot your love DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: Almost I had.

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: Negligent student! learn her by heart. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: By heart and in heart, boy.

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: And out of heart, master: all those three I will prove. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: What wilt thou prove

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: A man, if I live and this, by, in, and without, upon the instant: by heart you love her, because your heart cannot come by her in heart you love her, because your heart is in love with her and out of heart you love her, being out of heart that you cannot enjoy her. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: I am all these three.

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: And three times as much more, and yet nothing at all. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: Fetch hither the swain: he must carry me a letter.

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: A message well sympathized a horse to be ambassador for an ass. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: Ha, ha! what sayest thou

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: Marry, sir, you must send the ass upon the horse, for he is very slowgaited. But I go. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: The way is but short: away!

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: As swift as lead, sir. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: The meaning, pretty ingenious Is not lead a metal heavy, dull, and slow

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: Minime, honest master or rather, master, no. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: I say lead is slow.

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: You are too swift, sir, to say so: Is that lead slow which is fired from a gun DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: Sweet smoke of rhetoric! He reputes me a cannon and the bullet, thats he: I shoot thee at the swain.

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: Thump then and I flee. DON
Exit

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: A most acute juvenal voluble and free of grace! By thy favour, sweet welkin, I must sigh in thy face: Most rude melancholy, valour gives thee place. My herald is returnd.
Reenter MOTH with COSTARD

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: A wonder, master! heres a costard broken in a shin. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: Some enigma, some riddle: come, thy lenvoy begin.

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: No enigma, no riddle, no lenvoy no salve in the mail, sir: O, sir, plantain, a plain plantain! no lenvoy, no lenvoy no salve, sir, but a plantain! DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: By virtue, thou enforcest laughter thy silly thought my spleen the heaving of my lungs provokes me to ridiculous smiling. O, pardon me, my stars! Doth the inconsiderate take salve for lenvoy, and the word lenvoy for a salve

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: Do the wise think them other is not lenvoy a salve DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: No, page: it is an epilogue or discourse, to make plain Some obscure precedence that hath tofore been sain. I will example it: The fox, the ape, and the humblebee, Were still at odds, being but three. Theres the moral. Now the lenvoy.

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: I will add the lenvoy. Say the moral again. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: The fox, the ape, and the humblebee, Were still at odds, being but three.

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: Until the goose came out of door, And stayd the odds by adding four. Now will I begin your moral, and do you follow with my lenvoy. The fox, the ape, and the humblebee, Were still at odds, being but three. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: Until the goose came out of door, Staying the odds by adding four.

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: A good lenvoy, ending in the goose: would you desire more

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: The boy hath sold him a bargain, a goose, thats flat. Sir, your pennyworth is good, an your goose be fat. To sell a bargain well is as cunning as fast and loose: Let me see a fat lenvoy ay, thats a fat goose. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: Come hither, come hither. How did this argument begin

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: By saying that a costard was broken in a shin. Then calld you for the lenvoy.

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: True, and I for a plantain: thus came your argument in Then the boys fat lenvoy, the goose that you bought And he ended the market. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: But tell me how was there a costard broken in a shin

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: I will tell you sensibly.

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: Thou hast no feeling of it, Moth: I will speak that lenvoy: I Costard, running out, that was safely within, Fell over the threshold and broke my shin. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: We will talk no more of this matter.

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: Till there be more matter in the shin. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: Sirrah Costard, I will enfranchise thee.

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: O, marry me to one Frances: I smell some lenvoy, some goose, in this. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: By my sweet soul, I mean setting thee at liberty, enfreedoming thy person thou wert immured, restrained, captivated, bound.

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: True, true and now you will be my purgation and let me loose. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: I give thee thy liberty, set thee from durance and, in lieu thereof, impose on thee nothing but this: bear this significant to the country maid Jaquenetta: there is remuneration for the best ward of mine honour is rewarding my dependents. Moth, follow.
Giving a letter
Exit

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: Like the sequel, I. Signior Costard, adieu.

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: My sweet ounce of mans flesh! my incony Jew! Now will I look to his remuneration. Remuneration! O, thats the Latin word for three farthings: three farthingsremuneration.Whats the price of this inkleOne penny.No, Ill give you a remuneration: why, it carries it. Remuneration! why, it is a fairer name than French crown. I will never buy and sell out of this word.
Exit MOTH
Enter BIRON

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: O, my good knave Costard! exceedingly well met.

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: Pray you, sir, how much carnation ribbon may a man buy for a remuneration

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: What is a remuneration

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: Marry, sir, halfpenny farthing.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: Why, then, threefarthing worth of silk.

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: I thank your worship: God be wi you!

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: Stay, slave I must employ thee: As thou wilt win my favour, good my knave, Do one thing for me that I shall entreat.

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: When would you have it done, sir

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: This afternoon.

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: Well, I will do it, sir: fare you well.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: Thou knowest not what it is.

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: I shall know, sir, when I have done it.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: Why, villain, thou must know first.

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: I will come to your worship tomorrow morning.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: It must be done this afternoon. Hark, slave, it is but this: The princess comes to hunt here in the park, And in her train there is a gentle lady When tongues speak sweetly, then they name her name, And Rosaline they call her: ask for her And to her white hand see thou do commend This sealdup counsel. Theres thy guerdon go.
Giving him a shilling

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: Gardon, O sweet gardon! better than remuneration, alevenpence farthing better: most sweet gardon! I will do it sir, in print. Gardon! Remuneration!
Exit

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: And I, forsooth, in love! I, that have been loves whip A very beadle to a humorous sigh A critic, nay, a nightwatch constable A domineering pedant oer the boy Than whom no mortal so magnificent! This whimpled, whining, purblind, wayward boy This seniorjunior, giantdwarf, Dan Cupid Regent of loverhymes, lord of folded arms, The anointed sovereign of sighs and groans, Liege of all loiterers and malcontents, Dread prince of plackets, king of codpieces, Sole imperator and great general Of trotting paritors:O my little heart: And I to be a corporal of his field, And wear his colours like a tumblers hoop! What, I! I love! I sue! I seek a wife! A woman, that is like a German clock, Still arepairing, ever out of frame, And never going aright, being a watch, But being watchd that it may still go right! Nay, to be perjured, which is worst of all And, among three, to love the worst of all A wightly wanton with a velvet brow, With two pitchballs stuck in her face for eyes Ay, and by heaven, one that will do the deed Though Argus were her eunuch and her guard: And I to sigh for her! to watch for her! To pray for her! Go to it is a plague That Cupid will impose for my neglect Of his almighty dreadful little might. Well, I will love, write, sigh, pray, sue and groan: Some men must love my lady and some Joan. LOVES LABOURS LOST
Exit
